commitResults.messageTitle: Add AI.md for iP.AI development tracking
Level-0: Rename Duke to MONDAY and implement greet/exit functionality
commitResults.messageBody:
The project is using the Duke template from the course repository.

The project needs to be renamed to MONDAY to match the chosen chatbot
name with a grumpy personality inspired by Wednesday Addams.

Let's,
* rename Duke.java to Monday.java
* implement greet functionality that displays a grumpy greeting
* implement exit functionality that accepts an "exit" command
* update build.gradle to reference the new Monday class
* update test scripts to run Monday instead of Duke
* update test expectations and input files
* update documentation to reflect MONDAY branding

The greet and exit functionality provides the foundation for future
increments. All Duke references have been removed from the codebase.

commitResults.messageTitle: Level-0: Fix greet/exit to match grumpy personality
commitResults.messageBody:
The AI's initial implementation had a polite tone that contradicts MONDAY's intended grumpy personality.

MONDAY should be cynical (like Wednesday Addams) to appeal to power users who prefer efficiency over pleasantries.

Let's correct the greeting and exit messages to match the specified grumpy personality and add horizontal separators.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add command echoing and use 'bye' for exit
commitResults.messageBody:
The application does not echo user commands and uses 'exit' to quit.

Echoing commands provides feedback that input was received. Using 'bye'
as the exit command is more user-friendly and follows the specification.

Let's change the exit command from 'exit' to 'bye' and add echoing for
all non-exit commands to display user input wrapped in dividers.

The else block in the command loop handles the echoing case.

commitResults.messageTitle: Update AI.md with Level-1 Echo development log
Move Monday class to monday package and add Javadoc
commitResults.messageBody:
Monday.java is in the default package without documentation.

Using a proper package structure improves code organization and
follows Java conventions. Adding Javadoc improves code readability.

Let's,
* move Monday.java to the monday package
* add class-level Javadoc describing the chatbot
* add method-level Javadoc for the main method
* update build.gradle mainClass to monday.Monday
* update test scripts to use the new package path

commitResults.messageTitle: Add task storage and listing functionality
commitResults.messageBody:
MONDAY currently only echoes user input.

Users need a way to store and view tasks to make the chatbot useful for
task management.

Let's add an in-memory task list that can:
- Store up to 100 tasks
- Display tasks with numbered list format
- Handle edge cases (empty input, empty list, max tasks)

The implementation uses ArrayList for flexibility and maintains the grumpy
personality in all user messages.

commitResults.messageTitle: Update AI.md with Level-2 development log
Add mark and unmark commands for task completion status
commitResults.messageBody:
Tasks are stored as strings without any completion status tracking.

Users need a way to mark tasks as done and not done to track their
progress.

Let's add a Task class with completion status and implement mark/unmark
commands to toggle task completion state.

The Task class provides a foundation for future task enhancements such
as deadlines and event types.

commitResults.messageTitle: Refactor mark/unmark commands and improve code quality
commitResults.messageBody:
Mark and unmark commands are case-sensitive while list and bye commands
are case-insensitive. There is also code duplication between handleMark
and handleUnmark methods, magic strings in Task class, and redundant
.toString() calls in Monday class.

These issues reduce code maintainability and create inconsistent user
experience across commands.

Let's,
* make mark and unmark commands case-insensitive to match other commands
* extract shared logic from handleMark/handleUnmark into a helper method
* replace substring-based parsing with split on whitespace approach
* extract magic strings "[X]" and "[ ]" as constants in Task class
* make Task.description field final as it is never reassigned
* remove redundant .toString() calls when printing tasks
* update documentation examples to include LINE separators
* document case-insensitivity for mark/unmark commands

These changes improve code quality by following DRY principle, eliminating
magic strings, and ensuring consistent command behavior across the codebase.

commitResults.messageTitle: docs: Add Level-3 development log and workflow observations
Add support for todo, deadline, and event task types
commitResults.messageBody:
Tasks currently only support basic descriptions without date/time information.

Users need to track different types of tasks: simple todos, deadlines with due dates, and events with time ranges.

Let's,
* add getTypeIcon() and getFullDescription() methods to Task class
* create ToDo, Deadline, and Event subclasses extending Task
* add handleToDo(), handleDeadline(), and handleEvent() command handlers
* update command detection to recognize todo/deadline/event commands
* update text UI tests to verify all three task types
* update user documentation with examples for each command

The inheritance-based design allows polymorphism, so existing mark/unmark/list commands work without modification. Each task type displays with a unique icon ([T], [D], [E]) and includes type-specific details in the description.

commitResults.messageTitle: Fix exception handling to use specific types
Document Level-4 implementation in AI.md
Add dynamic greetings, help command, and exit alias
commitResults.messageBody:
Monday uses a static greeting message and only accepts "bye" to exit.
Users have no way to discover available commands without reading source
code. Some users may expect "exit" to work as a standard command.

These enhancements improve user experience while maintaining Monday's
grumpy personality throughout the application.

Let's,
* add getGrumpyGreeting() method that returns day-specific greetings
  using java.time.DayOfWeek
* add handleHelp() method to display all available commands with
  sarcastic descriptions
* accept both "bye" and "exit" commands to terminate the application
* update text UI tests to verify the new features work correctly

Using java.time.DayOfWeek provides accurate day detection without
external dependencies. The help command maintains Monday's personality
to stay consistent with the chatbot's character. Accepting "exit"
improves usability for users familiar with standard CLI conventions.

commitResults.messageTitle: Refactor greeting messages to use helper method
Response formatting: add blank lines around LINE separators
Text UI Testing: implement comprehensive automated tests
commitResults.messageBody:
Current testing only covers happy path scenarios.

Automated testing is needed to verify all command behaviors
and error conditions without manual testing.

Let's:
- Add 8 focused test files covering all commands and error paths
- Enhance test runners with pass/fail tracking and summary reports
- Test 13 unique error messages plus happy path scenarios
- Implement hybrid approach: multiple files for development,
  single combined file for grading submission

Test coverage includes:
- Empty input and empty list error handling
- Todo, deadline, and event command validation
- Mark/unmark validation (non-numeric, out of range)
- Case-insensitive command handling
- Edge cases (non-command input, exit alias)

commitResults.messageTitle: AI.md: document A-TextUiTesting increment
Error Handling: detect and reject all invalid user inputs
commitResults.messageBody:
Unknown commands and malformed inputs are currently being added as tasks.
Users receive no feedback when they enter invalid commands like "todo" (without
description) or unknown words like "blah".

Let's,
* Add helper methods to extract command words and validate known commands
* Refactor main command loop to use precise command detection
* Handle command-only inputs (e.g., "todo", "mark") with specific errors
* Show error messages for unknown commands instead of adding them as tasks
* Update test expectations to reflect new error handling behavior

This provides clear, immediate feedback for all invalid inputs while maintaining
MONDAY's grumpy personality throughout error messages.

commitResults.messageTitle: Code review: remove unused isKnownCommand() method
commitResults.messageBody:
The isKnownCommand() helper method was implemented but never used.
Command dispatch works through the if-else chain with a final else
block for unknown commands, making this method unnecessary.

This is a code quality cleanup based on reviewer feedback.

commitResults.messageTitle: AI.md: document Level-5 error handling increment
Add delete command to remove tasks from list
commitResults.messageBody:
Users cannot remove tasks from the list once added.

A delete command is needed for task management flexibility, allowing
users to remove completed or unwanted tasks.

Let's add a delete command that:
* adds handleTaskRemoval() helper method for task deletion logic
* adds handleDelete() wrapper method following mark/unmark pattern
* routes delete command in main() with proper error handling
* updates help text to include delete command
* adds comprehensive test cases for all delete scenarios

The implementation follows the existing mark/unmark command pattern
for consistency and reuses validation methods for error handling.

commitResults.messageTitle: AI.md: document Level-6 delete command increment
A-Enums: Use Java enums to replace hardcoded strings
commitResults.messageBody:
The codebase uses hardcoded strings for task icons, parameter prefixes,
and command words. These scattered string literals are error-prone and
make the code harder to maintain.

Using enums provides type safety, prevents typos, and centralizes all
constants in one place. Adding new commands or task types becomes
simpler and safer.

Let's introduce three Java enums:
* TaskType enum - centralizes task type icons ([T], [D], [E], [])
* TaskPrefix enum - centralizes parameter prefixes (/by, /from, /to)
* CommandType enum - centralizes command words with alias support

Enums demonstrate proper Java features including state (icon strings),
methods (getIcon(), getPrefix(), getCommand()), factory methods
(fromString()), and switch statement compatibility. The CommandType
enum also supports command aliases (e.g., "exit" â†’ "bye").

This improves code quality by providing compiler checks and IDE
auto-completion while maintaining all existing functionality.

commitResults.messageTitle: AI.md: document A-Enums increment
Greeting: add current date display and update help text formatting
commitResults.messageBody:
The greeting message does not show the current date, making the
day-specific message less contextual. Additionally, the help text
formatting could be improved for better readability.

Let's add a date display line before the day-specific message and update
the help text to use parenthetical formatting.

The date display helps users understand what day it is when seeing the
day-specific message, and the parenthetical format makes the help text
feel more conversational.

commitResults.messageTitle: Greeting: ensure English locale for date formatting
